And somehow we need something
to show us that we are
going in the wrong direction.

I don't think we're there yet,
but hopefully in six months,

a year, somehow nerves
will cool down a little bit

and people will start thinking

ZUBAIR RUSHK: I'm hoping that
I will not lose my citizenship.
That's my more considerate.

It's maybe, sometimes
for some people,

it's something that will never
happen, but I feel like it--
I don't know.

I have a feeling that's
one of the process, exactly

what it will be one of a process

SUZANNE AKHRAS
SAHLOUL: It started

with some of the
governors saying

that we don't want to welcome
Syrian refugees into our state.

Once that announcement
was made, we

had hundreds of
people reach out to us

asking how can
they help, how can
we support the Syrian people.

So if we want to look
at the good, we--

you can see that the
community, in fact,

became more informed about
what's happening in Syria

every time a politician would
say something and, in fact,

became more empathetic
and more supportive
of refugee resettlement.
